column1: Before 1 July 2019, will Daniel Ortega cease to be president of Nicaragua?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Leader Entry/Exit']
column11: Protests in response to government pension reforms have expanded to focus on Ortega, including calls for him to step down (The Washington Post, Reuters, ABC News). Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: Situation is relatively stable, protests have died down and Ortega recently released political prisoners, which should ease international pressure.
Claims are that all or at least a substantial percentage of his political prisoners have been released.

The regime of Daniel Ortega and Rosario Murillo won’t risk the international consequences of expropriating foreign citizens, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) in its latest report on Nicaragua. The publication also reiterates that the only vulnerable point of the regime is the possibility of greater United States sanctions. https://havanatimes.org/nicaragua/political-risk-in-nicaragua-is-extremely-high-says-the-economist/

Nicaragua is situated in a close proximity with Venezuela and the Venezuelian president is still in power, despite that the most of the public and international attention is focused on Maduro, not Ortega. Giving the example of Venezuela is helpful because Venezuela is from the same region with similar problems to Nicaragua- state run corruption, low economy,issues with law enforcement and daily disrespect of human rights, etc. Despite having different reasons which made both presidents to be seen by (part of) their citizens as illegitimate rulers, it is giving a significant analytical contrast for measuring how possible it is realistically currently Daniel Ortega to cease to be a president of Nicaragua before/after or in similar time with Venezualian President Nicolas Maduro. Moreover, as per today (17th May) Nicaragua seems to be a left out blind spot for the attention of politicians and all international attention of powers such as the US, UK, China, and even EU is consumed by other issues (Brexit, Venezuela, European elections, China, Boeing vs Airbus, etc, etc,) leaving Nicaragua to manage on itself without external pressures. The external pressures are important in measuring to what extent it is possible Ortega to leave his office at any point, not just in July. But with the interest being low in terms of Nicaragua and practically no external pressure except from NGOs, Ortega is in a more or less safe position to not be removed from power before July 2019. Some questions I think someone more proficient in Latin American politics can answer are: 1. Why is Nicaragua less important than Venezuela? 2. Is there any regional framework for cooperation that might influence such decisions and if not- why?

Thousands of Nicaraguans have protested President Daniel Ortega's Sandinista government after he implemented a pension reform which raised taxes and cut benefits. This reform was put in place as a result of the Sandinista's decade long misuse of funds which left the government insolvent. In addition, President Ortega has take steps over the years to slowly dismantle the country's democracy by stealing elections, reforming the constitution to his benefit, and bribing major media outlets. His actions have left citizens protesting for his removal, and the international community has done the same with the US placing sanctions on the country. Although there have been mass protests by citizens and condemnation by other countries, is is very unlikely that Ortega will cease to be president as he has remained in power unchallenged with the support of the Nicaraguan police and a gang known as the Sandinista Youth.
Ortega seems to be able to hold onto power and will find a way to remain until he is overthrown.
Dropping the last few points to zero, it seems his grip on power has solidified. This may change if Venezuela falls but that may also take a while.

Ortega has rejected a referendum on holding early elections believing that the opposition would not accept any unfavorable result. In late July the Ortega government faced pressure from international groups and sanctions from the United States. in mid-March Ortega announced the release of all people arrested during anti-Ortega protests.The violence between protestors and government forces has resulted in the death of 300 people and over 600 arrests.
Too close a date and have barely started talks with the opposition.

Over the past couple of elections in Nicaragua, it has been speculated that Daniel Ortega has undermined the electoral process and other branches of government. In doing so, he has managed to keep a hold on his position of power and rule with what many peg as an "iron fist". In wake of dialogues from the multiple protests spewing from over the years from human rights violations and economic struggle, President Ortega has agreed to release demonstration protesters who were arrested. As the government creates stricter limitations for opposition, talks have ensued about electoral reform. However, it is likely that President Ortega will remain in his position until after July 2019--potentially until the next election in 2021as he rejected efforts to move it up.

Recently the government also emphatically rejected calls for early elections scheduled for 2021, another central opposition demand. https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/fate-in-limbo-many-nicaraguan-exiles-struggle-in-costa-rica/2019/04/02/256b76f2-54fd-11e9-aa83-504f086bf5d6_story.html?utm_term=.2258c971f70a
Nicaragua: Yes to a Democratic Solution, No to an Ungovernable Country https://havanatimes.org/?p=150957

He vows to stay in power until 2021 when his term is up and he is making moves and concessions to meet this goal. His latest concession, just last week, was to release hundreds of prisoners who have been detained for nearly a year. While he may not be able to stay in power until 2021, he will likely last until July 2019.
Ortega has rejected out of hand another key opposition demand that he steps down and brings forward elections slated for 2021.

For a while the uprising looked set to dethrone Ortega, 73, whose cold war tussle with Washington made him a revolutionary icon but who is now increasingly seen as an autocrat. But a counter-attack by security forces and armed paramilitary gangs in July helped Ortega reclaim control of the streets and force thousands of dissidents into exile.

Political unrest in Nicaragua has caused the deaths of more than 300 anti-government protesters in the past year. Since July, President Ortega has repeatedly rejected calls for him to step down or to hold early elections. He has instead targeted the anti-government protesters, calling them terrorists. In the past few months, the government has increasingly cracked down on protesters. The movement appears to be dying down as a result of the government's aggressive actions. Furthermore, protesters do not have enough leverage against the President, who over the years has consolidated political power. His wife is the vice president, and they currently have control over the judiciary, parliament, armed forces, and police. All this suggests that it is unlikely that Ortega will cease to be President of Nicaragua by July 1st, 2019
OAS Weighs Options for Confronting the Nicaraguan Crisis https://havanatimes.org/?p=142627

Ortega has been beaten at the polls before, and he can be again. Rather than risk further violence, the will likely wait until the next election. An electoral victory over Ortega will also carry more international legitimacy than an armed uprising.

Ortega has spend decades building political immunity and power. The next election is late 2020, and the government is stacked with his supporters. Unless he decides to resign, which he has repeatedly refused to do, he will remain in office. I suppose if he died, that would also resolve the question.

Daniel Ortega, Nicaragua's President, stands accused of unleashing a wave of violent reprisals by government forces against opposition groups. Press accounts list the death toll at over 300 protestors. The attention of the Organization of American States (OAS), of which the U.S. is a permanent member state, has shifted towards Ortega's Nicaragua as international accounts paint a dire picture of a despotic regime. Allegations of human rights violations have drawn the condemnation of the OAS Secretary General. The situation seems to be escalating. Amnesty International now believes it has evidence of extrajudicial killings. Ortega, who assumed power in the 70s after leading a revolution, refuses to transition power after four terms in office. Considering the U.S. history of intervention in Nicaragua in the form of the Contras during the 1980s, and the nations history of violence, there certainly is a quiet potential for internal or external action that could lead to ousting Ortega from office.

I think that there is the chance that Ortega's regime will be toppled before next July, but it's relatively unlikely as he has been clinging to power for some time that he would not simply step down or be dramatically forced out, as it likely would have already happened with the height of the protests earlier this year. The next elections are not due until 2020, so unless there is a threat of violence that would force Ortega out of office, he would likely not be taken out of power until 2020, and that is only if the elections are not rigged in his favor. So there are basically two likely outcomes for the transition of power: either Ortega is forcefully/violently removed from office, like Allende was in Chile through a violent military coup with outside (US) support, which is unlikely since the international community will likely not get involved militarily or through the use of violence; alternatively, if there is enough international pressure, it is possible that Ortega would leave office relatively voluntarily after the 2020 election, as Pinochet did in Chile at the end of the 1980s based on domestic and international concern and protests. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nicaragua-protests-usa/nicaraguas-ortega-rejects-early-elections-u-s-rebukes-crackdown-idUSKBN1KK1OWhttps://www.reuters.com/article/us-nicaragua-protests-usa/nicaraguas-ortega-rejects-early-elections-u-s-rebukes-crackdown-idUSKBN1KK1OW https://www.pri.org/stories/2018-08-21/venezuelan-oil-fueled-rise-and-fall-nicaraguas-ortega-regime

Different social sectors that oppose Daniel Ortega’s dictatorship, including the Civic Alliance and the Articulation of Social Movements, have decided to join forces and create a “common front” called “Unidad Nacional Azul y Blanco” (Blue and White National Unity, putting aside their differences about how to tackle the current socio-political crisis that has taken over the country. https://todaynicaragua.com/nicaragua-has-a-new-united-front-in-opposition-to-ortega/

WASHINGTON—The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) issued an advisory today to alert U.S. financial institutions of the increasing risk that proceeds of political corruption from Nicaragua may enter or traverse the U.S. financial system. FinCEN expects that senior foreign political figures connected to the regime of Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega could react to the perceived threat of further unrest, potential sanctions, or other factors by moving assets out of their accounts in Nicaragua or elsewhere. These assets could be the proceeds of corruption, and they may be directed into U.S. accounts, or laundered through the U.S. financial system. FinCEN requests that financial institutions file Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs), consistent with their existing Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) obligations, when they identify potential misuse of Nicaraguan public funds or potential proceeds of political corruption associated with senior foreign political figures connected to the Ortega regime. Based on the history of conflict due to President Ortega, it seems likely that this violence will escalate. President Ortega made changes to the constitution in 2006 in order to stay in office, and despite negative backlash from the public, he continues to fight for power. Since April of 2018, many protesters have died in uprisings calling for Ortega to leave office, and those protests have been met with military force. The protests are composed of people who are multi-ethnic, come from separate political factions as well as economic backgrounds, and the international community has condemned the actions of the government of Nicaragua. Despite condemnation and backlash from thousands of people from the country, Ortega continues to use military and political power to hold his seat. He used his immunity to prevent trial for allegations of child abuse from his step-daughter, and has also shown many other instances of high-level corruption. Because Ortega is willing to go to extremes to remain president and to have this position of power, it is unlikely that he will leave office within one year. Due to the unstable nature and violence insinuated by the protests, it is unlikely that the movement will make an effect until there is a uniting force, which is unlikely before July of 2019. It is unlikely because although businesses have began to feel the effects of the corruption from the presidency, they do not have that much of a voice in Nicaragua because it's one of the poorest countries in Nicaragua. The widespread poverty does not allow for a strong business influence in stopping Ortega, so although they are against Ortega, external influence needs to be implemented. Based off history of international institutions and intervention, in order for them to act, the crisis needs to be more widespread, or national interests of powerful states must be aligned with the politics of Nicaragua. Since the end of the Cold War, the U.S. has not had interests in Nicaragua because the military is no longer aimed at combating communists, but instead terrorists. Other powerful world actors have not indicated interests in Nicaragua either, so it is unlikely there will be an intervention besides sanctions before escalation, which is unlikely to happen until protests become more organized and widespread, which will not happen before July of 2019 due to the chaos in the organization of protests and violence happening currently.

Ortega has stated he will not step down and not enact any elections prior to 2021. He still controls the government, military, police and much of the Nicaraguan business interests, including state media. For him to cease to be president in the next 12 months it would require, assassination, revolution, personal illness, or intervention by another country (most probable the US). Another alternative, he could step down and allow someone in his close circle or family to assume the presidency to calm the unrest.
